title: DHS Algebra 1
text:
Welcome to Algebra 1
Welcome to Algebra 1 at Frederick Douglass High School!
This book will guide you through the most important math skills you‚Äôll need to succeed in high school and beyond. Algebra is more than just solving equations ‚Äî it‚Äôs a powerful way to understand patterns, solve problems, and think logically.
Whether you‚Äôre reviewing old ideas or learning something brand new, this book is here to help you every step of the way.

title: DHS Algebra 1
section: üß≠ What You‚Äôll Find in This Book
text:
üß≠ What You‚Äôll Find in This Book
Each unit includes:

Clear goals to help you focus
Examples and explanations
Practice problems
Activities to explore and talk through ideas

We‚Äôll start with the basics ‚Äî like working with numbers and fractions ‚Äî and build up to more complex ideas like equations, graphs, and even quadratics.
You don‚Äôt have to be a ‚Äúmath person‚Äù to do well here. Just bring your curiosity, a little patience, and the willingness to try.
Let‚Äôs get started!

title: Introduction
text:
What You‚Äôll Learn
Welcome to Unit 1! In this unit, we‚Äôll build the foundation you need to succeed in Algebra. Think of this as preparing your math toolkit.
You‚Äôll explore integers, factors, fractions, and the rules of simplification. These skills are the building blocks that will help you solve more complex problems with confidence ‚Äî especially when working with expressions and equations in later units.
By the end of this unit, you‚Äôll be able to:

title: Introduction
text:
Work with positive and negative numbers on a number line
Use factor trees to find prime factorizations
Identify and use the greatest common factor (GCF)
Convert between fractions, decimals, and percents
Multiply, divide, and compare fractions
Follow the correct order of operations to simplify expressions

title: Introduction
text:
Topics in This Unit
Integers & Number Lines Understand and use positive and negative numbers, and how to place them on a number line.
Factors, Multiples & Prime Factorization Break numbers into their prime building blocks using factor trees.
GCF & Simplifying Fractions Use prime factorization to find the GCF and simplify fractions to their simplest form.
Fractions, Decimals & Percents Convert between different number forms and apply them in real-world problems.
Multiply, Divide & Compare Fractions Work with fractions in ways that actually show up in Algebra ‚Äî simplify, multiply, divide, and compare.
Order of Operations Follow the rules (PEMDAS) to simplify numeric expressions with integers and fractions.

Let‚Äôs build those Algebra muscles ‚Äî you‚Äôll need them for everything that follows!

title: 1.1 - Integers & Number Lines
text:
üî• Warm-Up
Did you know that all of mathematics is actually built up from simple things like counting? Even advanced topics like algebra and calculus are just clever ways of organizing and extending basic ideas ‚Äî like moving forward and backward on a number line.
In this lesson, we‚Äôll use the number line not just to count, but to add, subtract, and compare positive and negative numbers. That might sound basic, but it‚Äôs the foundation of nearly everything else you‚Äôll do in Algebra.
Negative numbers can be tricky, especially when the rules don‚Äôt always match what your gut tells you. But if you can master the way they work on the number line ‚Äî including things like opposites, absolute value, and comparison ‚Äî you‚Äôll be setting yourself up for success in the rest of the course.
Answer as best you can ‚Äì even if you aren‚Äôt sure!

title: 1.1 - Integers & Number Lines
text:
What is the opposite of 6?
Which is greater -4 or -9?
Which is farther from 0: -7 or 5?

title: 1.1 - Integers & Number Lines
text:
üë• Learn Together

1.1.1 - The Number Line Is More Than Just Counting
You already know how to count ‚Äî 0, 1, 2, 3, and so on. The number line extends that idea in both directions.
Let‚Äôs draw a number line from -10 to 10 
Here, every tick mark is an integer ‚Äî a whole number.

Numbers to the right of zero are positive
Numbers to the left of zero are negative

We can use this number line to see what happens when we add, subtract, or compare numbers.
Are there other ways to draw a number line?
Yes! Number lines can be drawn over different ranges and scales. For example, here is a number line that counts form -10 to 25 in steps of 5.

In fact, number lines don‚Äôt even have to be horizontal. Here is a vertical number line that goes from 0 to 100 in steps of 10.







üß† Can you think of any real world examples of number lines?





Here are a few examples:

thermometer
ruler
timeline
American football field
volume slider on a phone










How many numbers are between 3 and 5?



Though there are 2 integers between 3 and 5, the answer is not 2! There are infinitely many numbers between 3 and 5. Here are some number lines that might help convince you.
  





1.1.2 - Understanding Opposites
Let‚Äôs look at a pair of numbers, 3 and -3.
These are called opposite numbers. They are the same distance from zero but on opposite sides of it.







üß† What is the opposite of zero?





The opposite of zero is zero. Zero is the only number that is its own opposite!






1.1.3 - What Is Absolute Value?
Absolute value (\(|number|\)) measures the distance from zero, no matter the direction.
Take a look at the number -5. The number line shows that it‚Äôs absolute value is 5 because it is 5 units away from zero. 
You can see that |5| is also 5 for the same reason! 






üåç In the Real World



Absolute value is often used for describing the distance between two points. Suppose you live 3 miles to the east of the school and your best friend lives 5 miles to the west. How far apart are your houses? This is easy to see with a number line.

You can compute your distances by adding |-5| + |3|, by |-5 - 3|, or by |3 - (-5)|. All three of these give the same answer, 8 miles. What would change if we did not use absolute value?








üß† Can the absolute value ever be negative?





Absolute value is never negative, because distance is never negative.






1.1.4 - Comparing Integers
We can also use the number line to compare values.
Let‚Äôs compare 2 to -7. 
You can see from the number line that 2 is greater than (>) -7 because 2 is to the right of -7.
You can also see that -7 is further from zero than 2 and so |-7| > |2|.






Which is bigger?



It is easy to get confused here. When we say which is ‚Äúbigger‚Äù we are asking which number is further to the right on the number line, not which one is furthest from zero.








üß† Try comparing 3 to -8 using a number line.





3 > -8 because it is farther to the right but |-8| > |3| because -8 is further from zero.







1.1.5 - Number Lines and Arithmetic
We can also use the number line to model adding and subtracting integers.

To add a positive number, move right
To add a negative number, move left

Examples:

Addition: \(-2 + 6 = 4\) 







üåç In the Real World



Imagine that you are $2 in debt. If someone pays you $6 you can pay off the debt and have $\(4\) left over.



Adding a negative: \(150 + (-5) = 145\) 







üåç In the Real World



You have $150 in the bank. The bank ads a fee for being under their $200 minimum balance. You now have $145.



Subtraction: \(400 - 450 = -50\) 







üåç In the Real World



If you only have $400 but spend $450 on a credit card. You are now $50 in debt.



Subtracting a negative: \(201 - (-5) = 206\) 







üß† Can You think of a real-world example for the previous example?






Example: The bank made a mistake, you had $\(201\) in your account so they took off the $\(5\) fee. Now you have $\(206\).

title: 1.2 - Factors, Multiples & Prime Factorization
text:
üî• Warm-Up
Have you ever had to split something up evenly ‚Äî like slices of pizza or players on a team? That‚Äôs really what factors are about: dividing numbers into equal parts.
In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to:
You‚Äôll use these skills again and again ‚Äî from simplifying fractions to solving equations.

title: 1.2 - Factors, Multiples & Prime Factorization
text:
List all the whole-number factors of 12.
Find a multiple of 7 that is less than 50.
Is 11 a prime number? How do you know?

title: 1.2 - Factors, Multiples & Prime Factorization
text:
üë• Learn Together

1.2.1 - What Are Factors?
A factor of a number is a whole number that divides it evenly ‚Äî with no remainder.
Example:
The factors of 12 are: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6 and 2
That‚Äôs because:
1 √ó 12 = 12
2 √ó 6 = 12
3 √ó 4 = 12






üß† Can a number have just one factor?





Only one number does: 1. It only has itself as a factor and so it is neither prime nor composite!






1.2.2 - What Are Multiples?
A multiple is what you get when you multiply a number by 1, 2, 3, 4‚Ä¶
Example:
Here are the first few multiples of 5:
\(5, 10, 15, 20, 25, 30, ...\)
Multiples are useful when finding common denominators or common multiples later in algebra.
Where have we seen this before?
Multiples show up all over the place. When you skip count, you are using multiples. In the previous lesson, we used multiples to constuct number lines!
Example:
Here is a number line that shows multiples of three. 



1.2.3 - Prime vs.¬†Composite
A prime number has only 2 factors: 1 and itself. Examples: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11, 13‚Ä¶
A composite number has more than 2 factors. Examples: 4, 6, 8, 9, 10‚Ä¶






üåç In the Real World



Prime numbers play a big role in encryption, which keeps your data safe when you shop or message online.





1.2.4 - Prime Factorization and Factor Trees
Every number can be broken into a product of prime numbers ‚Äî sort of like breaking a LEGO¬Æ sculpture into individual bricks. These prime factors are the basic building blocks of all whole numbers.
We use factor trees to find these prime factors. This isn‚Äôt just a fun trick ‚Äî it builds your number sense: your ability to see patterns, understand how numbers are structured, and work confidently with them.
That number sense will come in handy later when you:

Simplify fractions
Solve equations
Factor algebraic expressions
Find common denominators

Let‚Äôs build a factor tree for 360 to see how it works.


Steps to Make a Factor Tree

Start with a number:







flowchart TB
    node_0("360")




Figure¬†1






Find any two numbers that multiply to give the number: \(360 = 18 √ó 20\)

    node_1_1_1("20")

Figure¬†2






Break each of those numbers down further:

\(18 = 3 √ó 6\)
\(20 = 4 √ó 5\)








flowchart TB
    node_0("360")
    node_1_0_1("18")

    node_1_1_2_1_2("5")
    node_1_1_1 --> node_1_1_2_1_2




Figure¬†3






Keep going until all branches end in prime numbers (numbers that can‚Äôt be factored anymore, like 2, 3, 5, 7‚Ä¶). We call the ends of the branches ‚Äúleaves‚Äù.

Figure¬†4






The prime factorization is the product of the leaves of the tree:  \[2 * 2 * 2 * 3 * 3 * 5 = 360\] This can be written more compactly by using the factor counts as exponents. There are three 2s and two 3s in this case and so we get‚Ä¶ \[2^3 * 3^2 * 5 = 360\]








Tip



There are many factor trees for the number 360. For example, you could also have started with \(360 = 3 * 120\).

There are still three 2s, two 3s, and one 5, so the prime factorization does not change! \[2^3 * 3^2 * 5 = 360\] As long as you end up with the same prime numbers, the tree is correct!


What About Negative Numbers?
If the number is negative, factor out a -1 first. Here is one possible factor tree for -24:

title: 1.3 ‚Äì GCF & Simplifying Fractions
text:
üî• Warm-Up
Ever tried to share something fairly ‚Äî like splitting snacks or organizing teams into equal groups? That‚Äôs the idea behind the greatest common factor, or GCF. It tells us how much we can evenly divide into two or more numbers.
In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to use prime factorization to find the GCF, and how that can help us simplify fractions. These aren‚Äôt just number tricks ‚Äî they help you write expressions in cleaner, simpler ways so they‚Äôre easier to work with.

title: 1.3 ‚Äì GCF & Simplifying Fractions
text:
List the prime factorization of:

20
45

What‚Äôs the largest number that divides both 12 and 18 evenly?
Write a fraction equal to \(\frac{12}{20}\) using smaller numbers.

title: 1.3 ‚Äì GCF & Simplifying Fractions
text:
üë• Learn Together

1.3.1 ‚Äì What Is the Greatest Common Factor?
The greatest common factor (GCF) is the biggest number that divides evenly into two or more numbers.
Let‚Äôs look at 18 and 24.
Factors of 18: 1, 2, 3, 6, 9, 18 Factors of 24: 1, 2, 3, 4, 6, 8, 12, 24 The GCF is 6 ‚Äî it‚Äôs the largest factor they both share.



1.3.2 ‚Äì Use Prime Factorization to Find the GCF
We can also find the GCF using prime factorization.
Let‚Äôs try 36 and 60.
Prime factorization: 36 = 2 √ó 2 √ó 3 √ó 3 60 = 2 √ó 2 √ó 3 √ó 5
The GCF is the product of the shared prime factors: 2 √ó 2 √ó 3 = 12
This method works even when the numbers are large or hard to list out.



1.3.3 ‚Äì Simplifying Fractions with the GCF
Let‚Äôs say you have the fraction \(\frac{36}{60}\). Both numbers share a GCF of 12, so:
\[
\frac{36 \div 12}{60 \div 12} = \frac{3}{5}
\]
You‚Äôve simplified the fraction ‚Äî but it still means the same thing.
This is called an equivalent fraction.






Why Not Just Divide by 2?



You can simplify step-by-step, but using the GCF gets the job done in one move.





1.3.4 ‚Äì Real-World Example
Suppose you‚Äôre planning gift bags. You have 60 pencils and 36 erasers and want to make identical bags with no extras.
What‚Äôs the most you can make?

Find the GCF of 60 and 36 ‚Üí 12

You can make 12 bags, each with: 60 √∑ 12 = 5 pencils 36 √∑ 12 = 3 erasers

title: 1.3 ‚Äì GCF & Simplifying Fractions
text:
‚úçÔ∏è Practice On Your Own

title: 1.4 ‚Äì Fractions, Decimals & Percents
text:
üî• Warm-Up
Did you know that ¬Ω, 0.5, and 50% are all the same amount?
In real life, we use fractions, decimals, and percents to describe parts of a whole ‚Äî whether it‚Äôs sale prices, test scores, or how much of a task is finished.
In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to convert between these forms and use them in real-world problems. Being able to move between them will make you faster, more flexible, and more confident in math.

title: 1.4 ‚Äì Fractions, Decimals & Percents
text:
What is ¬Ω as a decimal? As a percent?
Which is more: 0.75 or 2‚ÅÑ3?
What percent is the same as 3‚ÅÑ4?

title: 1.4 ‚Äì Fractions, Decimals & Percents
text:
üë• Learn Together

1.4.1 ‚Äì What Are These Numbers Really Saying?
All three number types describe a part of a whole:



Fraction

‚úî They look different, but they mean the same thing.




1.4.2 ‚Äì Converting Between Forms

Fraction ‚Üí Decimal
Divide the top by the bottom Example: 3‚ÅÑ4 ‚Üí 3 √∑ 4 = 0.75


Decimal ‚Üí Percent
Move the decimal two places to the right (√ó100) 0.75 ‚Üí 75%


Percent ‚Üí Decimal
Move the decimal two places left (√∑100) 25% ‚Üí 0.25


Decimal ‚Üí Fraction
Say the number out loud 0.6 = ‚Äúsix tenths‚Äù = 6‚ÅÑ10 ‚Üí simplify to 3‚ÅÑ5




1.4.3 ‚Äì Benchmarks Help You Think Fast
These values come up a lot ‚Äî know them by heart:

1.4.4 ‚Äì Real-Life Uses
You‚Äôll see these forms all the time:

Shopping: 20% off = pay 80% of the price
Grades: 17 out of 20 = 85%
Weather: 30% chance of rain

A store is having a 25% off sale. That means you only pay 75% of the price. If a jacket costs $60, then:
60 √ó 0.75 = $45 ‚Üí That‚Äôs your sale price.

title: 1.5 ‚Äì Multiply, Divide & Compare Fractions
text:
üî• Warm-Up
In Algebra, you‚Äôll work with fractions all the time ‚Äî but not usually adding and subtracting them. What matters most is knowing how to multiply, divide, and simplify fractions to make expressions easier to work with.
In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn how to multiply and divide fractions with confidence, and how to compare them logically. These are skills you‚Äôll use throughout Algebra ‚Äî especially when solving equations and simplifying rational expressions.

title: 1.5 ‚Äì Multiply, Divide & Compare Fractions
text:
What‚Äôs ‚Öî of 12?
What‚Äôs the reciprocal of 4‚ÅÑ5?
Is ¬æ greater than ‚Öî? How do you know?

title: 1.5 ‚Äì Multiply, Divide & Compare Fractions
text:
üë• Learn Together

1.5.1 ‚Äì Multiplying Fractions
Multiply straight across:
Numerators √ó Numerators Denominators √ó Denominators
Example:
\[
\frac{2}{3} \times \frac{5}{6} = \frac{2 \times 5}{3 \times 6} = \frac{10}{18}
\]
Simplify: 10‚ÅÑ18 ‚Üí 5‚ÅÑ9
If possible, simplify before multiplying:
\[
\frac{4}{5} \times \frac{10}{12} = \frac{2}{5} \times \frac{5}{6} = \frac{2 \times 5}{5 \times 6} = \frac{10}{30} = \frac{1}{3}
\]



1.5.2 ‚Äì Multiplying Mixed Numbers
Step 1: Convert to improper fractions Step 2: Multiply Step 3: Simplify if needed
Example: 1¬Ω √ó 2‚ÅÑ3 ‚Üí 1¬Ω = 3‚ÅÑ2 ‚Üí 3‚ÅÑ2 √ó 2‚ÅÑ3 = 6‚ÅÑ6 = 1



1.5.3 ‚Äì Dividing Fractions
To divide fractions, multiply by the reciprocal (flip the second fraction):
Example:
\[
\frac{3}{4} \div \frac{2}{5} = \frac{3}{4} \times \frac{5}{2} = \frac{15}{8}
\]
Mixed number: 1‚Öû






Don‚Äôt flip the first fraction!



Only flip the second fraction ‚Äî the one you‚Äôre dividing by.





1.5.4 ‚Äì Comparing Fractions

Method 1: Use Benchmarks
Estimate which is closer to ¬Ω, ‚Öî, or 1.


Method 2: Use Common Denominators
Compare ‚Öî and ¬æ ‚Üí ‚Öî = 8‚ÅÑ12 ‚Üí ¬æ = 9‚ÅÑ12 ‚úî So ¬æ is greater.


Method 3: Cross Multiply
\[
\frac{3}{5} \quad \text{vs.} \quad \frac{2}{3} \\
3 \times 3 = 9 \\
5 \times 2 = 10 \\
\text{Since 10 > 9, } \frac{2}{3} > \frac{3}{5}
\]




1.5.5 ‚Äì Why This Matters in Algebra
You‚Äôll use fraction multiplication and division when:

Solving equations with fractional coefficients
Simplifying rational expressions
Finding slope
Working with proportions







üåç In the Real World



You‚Äôre painting a wall. The can says it covers ‚Öî of a room. You buy 3 cans. How much will it cover?
3 √ó ‚Öî = 2 ‚Üí Enough for 2 rooms

2. Division

2‚ÅÑ5 √ó 4‚ÅÑ3 = 8‚ÅÑ15
4‚ÅÑ3 √∑ 2‚ÅÑ3 = 4‚ÅÑ3 √ó 3‚ÅÑ2 = 12‚ÅÑ6 = 2
9‚ÅÑ10 √∑ 3‚ÅÑ5 = 9‚ÅÑ10 √ó 5‚ÅÑ3 = 45‚ÅÑ30 = 3‚ÅÑ2 = 1¬Ω


3. Comparisons

title: 1.6 ‚Äì Order of Operations
text:
üî• Warm-Up
What does this equal?
\[
6 + 2 \times 3
\]
If you said 24 ‚Äî you‚Äôre not alone. But that‚Äôs not the correct answer. Math has rules for what to do first. These rules are called the order of operations, and they‚Äôre essential for simplifying expressions the right way.
In this lesson, you‚Äôll learn to follow those rules consistently ‚Äî even when negatives, fractions, and grouping are involved.

title: 1.6 ‚Äì Order of Operations
text:
Simplify: 3 + 6 √ó 2
True or False: (4 + 3) √ó 2 = 4 + (3 √ó 2)
What does ¬Ω √ó (4 + 2) equal?

title: 1.6 ‚Äì Order of Operations
text:
üë• Learn Together

1.6.1 ‚Äì The Order Matters
The correct order is:
P ‚Äì Parentheses E ‚Äì Exponents MD ‚Äì Multiply or Divide (left to right) AS ‚Äì Add or Subtract (left to right)
This is often remembered as PEMDAS.

‚ö†Ô∏è Multiply doesn‚Äôt always come before divide. Same with add and subtract. You go left to right when they appear together.




1.6.2 ‚Äì Basic Examples



\[
5 + 3 \times 2 = 5 + 6 = 11
\]



\[
(5 + 3) \times 2 = 8 \times 2 = 16
\]



\[
8 - 12 √∑ 3 = 8 - 4 = 4
\]



1.6.3 ‚Äì Include Negatives & Fractions
Watch how signs and simplification interact:
Example 1:
\[
-3 \times (4 - 7) = -3 \times (-3) = 9
\]
Example 2:
\[
\frac{1}{2} \times (6 + 2) = \frac{1}{2} \times 8 = 4
\]
Example 3:
\[
\frac{3 + 5}{2} = \frac{8}{2} = 4
\]






Be careful with negatives!



\(-3^2\) means \(-(3^2) = -9\) but \((-3)^2 = 9\)





1.6.4 ‚Äì Complex Expressions
Put it all together:
Example:
\[
4 + \frac{1}{2} \times (6 - 2)^2
\]
Step 1: Parentheses ‚Üí (6 - 2) = 4 Step 2: Exponents ‚Üí 4¬≤ = 16 Step 3: Multiply ‚Üí ¬Ω √ó 16 = 8 Step 4: Add ‚Üí 4 + 8 = 12



1.6.5 ‚Äì Why This Matters in Algebra
Later, expressions will include:

Variables
Distributive property
Combining like terms

If students can‚Äôt simplify numbers correctly, the algebra won‚Äôt work either.






üåç In the Real World



You get a 25% off coupon and a $10 gift card. The item costs $40. Which should be applied first?
25% of 40 = $10 ‚Üí pay $30, then gift card = $20 But 40 - 10 = 30, then 25% off = $22.50
The order changes the result!

\]







üîë Answer Key





1. Basic

2. Negatives/Fractions

3. Expressions

4. Challenge

5. Final Problem

title: Glossary
text:
Absolute value
The distance a number is from zero on a number line, always expressed as a positive number or zero.

Example: The absolute value of -7 is 7.




Algebra
Algebra is a branch of math that uses letters and symbols to represent numbers and relationships.
It lets us describe patterns, write rules, and solve problems that work in many different situations.



Calculus
Calculus is a branch of math that helps us understand change and motion.
It‚Äôs used to study how fast things move, how things grow or shrink, and how to find exact areas or curves.



Composite number
A composite number has more than two factors.
That means it can be divided evenly by numbers other than 1 and itself.

Example: 12 is composite because 2, 3, 4, and 6 all divide it evenly.




Denominator
The denominator is the bottom number in a fraction. It tells how many equal parts the whole is divided into.

Example: In the fraction \(\frac{3}{4}\), the denominator is 4.




Equation
An equation is a math sentence that says two things are equal.
It has an equals sign (=) and shows a relationship between numbers or expressions.

Examples: 2 + 3 = 5 and x + 1 = 7




Expression
An expression is a math phrase made of numbers, variables, or both ‚Äî but it doesn‚Äôt have an equals sign.

Examples: 3x + 2 7 ‚àí y 5(a ‚àí 1)




Factor
A factor is a whole number that divides another number evenly ‚Äî with no remainder.
If you can split something into equal groups with no leftovers, the group size is a factor.

Example: 3 is a factor of 12 because 3 √ó 4 = 12.




Factoring
Factoring means breaking something down into smaller parts that multiply together to make it.

Examples:

Factoring a number: 12 can be factored into 3 √ó 4 or 2 √ó 6.
Factoring an expression: x¬≤ + 5x + 6 can be factored into (x + 2)(x + 3).





Factor tree
A factor tree is a way to break a number into its smallest building blocks ‚Äî the prime numbers that multiply to make it.
You keep splitting the number into smaller factors until you can‚Äôt go any further.

Example: Here is a factor tree for 24:






flowchart TD
   A[24]
   A --> B[6]
   A --> C[4]
   B --> D[3]
   B --> E[2]
   C --> F[2]
   C --> G[2]







This tells us that the prime factorization of 24 is \(2^3 \cdot 3\).




Fraction
A fraction shows a part of a whole. It has a numerator (top number) and a denominator (bottom number).
The denominator tells how many equal parts the whole is divided into, and the numerator tells how many of those parts you have.

Example: In \(\frac{3}{4}\), the fraction means 3 out of 4 equal parts.




Greater than
A number is greater than (>) another number if it is further to the right on the number line.

Example: 5 > 3 is true  but 3 > 5 is false 




Horizontal
Side to side, like the horizon. Level ground is horizontal.

Example: This is a horizontal number line. 




Integer
An integer is a whole number (not a fraction or decimal) that can be positive, negative, or zero.

Examples: -3, 0, 5, 100




Less than
A number is less than (<) another number if it is further to the left on the number line.

Example: 3 < 5 is true  but 5 < 3 is false 




Multiple
A multiple is what you get when you multiply a number by 1, 2, 3, and so on.

Example: 5, 10, 15, and 20 are all multiples of 5.




Number line
A straight line used to show numbers in order. It usually has zero in the middle, with positive numbers to the right and negative numbers to the left.
Number lines help you visualize math operations and compare values.

Example: -2, 0, and 3 are all on the number line. 




Number sense
Number sense is a person‚Äôs ability to understand, work with, and think about numbers.
In simple terms, it means having a good feel for how numbers work ‚Äî like knowing:

What numbers mean
How they relate to each other
How to break them apart or put them together
What a reasonable answer might be

People with strong number sense can do mental math, estimate, recognize patterns, and spot when something ‚Äúdoesn‚Äôt make sense.‚Äù
It‚Äôs kind of like having a good instinct for numbers ‚Äî not just memorizing rules, but really getting how numbers behave.



Numerator
The numerator is the top number in a fraction. It tells how many parts you have.

Example: In the fraction \(\frac{3}{4}\), the numerator is 3.




Negative
A number is negative if it is less than zero.
On a number line, negative numbers are to the left of zero.

Example: -4 is a negative number.




Opposite
Two numbers that are the same distance from zero on a number line, but on opposite sides.
Their sum is always zero.

Example: -3 and 3 are opposites.




Positive
A number is positive if it is greater than zero.
On a number line, positive numbers are to the right of zero.

Example: 5 is a positive number.




Prime Number
A number is prime if it has exactly two factors: 1 and itself.

Examples: 2, 3, 5, 7, 11




Prime factorization
Prime factorization means writing a number as a product of prime numbers.

Example: 18 = 2 √ó 3 √ó 3 or 2 √ó 3¬≤

These are the prime building blocks of 18.



Product
A product is the result of multiplying two or more numbers.

Example: The product of 4 and 6 is 24, because 4 √ó 6 = 24.




Quotient
A quotient is the result of dividing one number by another.

Example: The quotient of 20 divided by 5 is 4, because 20 √∑ 5 = 4.




Remainder
A remainder is what‚Äôs left over after dividing when the number doesn‚Äôt go in evenly.

Example: 10 √∑ 3 = 3 with a remainder of 1, because 3 √ó 3 = 9 and there‚Äôs 1 left.




Sum
A sum is the result of adding two or more numbers.

Example: The sum of 7 and 8 is 15, because 7 + 8 = 15.




Vertical
Up and down, like a flagpole.

Example: This is a vertical number line.
